qa_pairs.question: How did the diplomatic representation between Hong Kong and Malaysia evolve from the British colonial era to the post-1997 period, and what is the current structure of their consular relations?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The diplomatic representation between Hong Kong and Malaysia evolved from the British colonial era to the post-1997 period, transitioning from a British-era "Commission" to a modern Consulate General. During the British rule, Malaysia's mission in Hong Kong was designated as a **Commission**, reflecting the status of Commonwealth countries at the time. This structure changed after Hong Kong's handover in 1997, when the Commission was renamed the Consulate General, and the head of mission became a Consul-General instead of a Commissioner.<cite>[S7][S8][S9][S10]</cite></statement><statement>Currently, Malaysia maintains a Consulate General in Wan Chai, Hong Kong, established on 2 July 1971. This consulate is led by the current Consul-General, Yap Wei Sin, who took office in March 2019. Additionally, Hong Kong's formal diplomatic relations with Malaysia are managed by the Chinese Embassy in Kuala Lumpur, as Hong Kong is a Special Administrative Region of China.<cite>[S7][S10][S11][S4]</cite></statement><statement>Malaysia's consular presence in Hong Kong also includes the Hong Kong Trade and Development Council in Kuala Lumpur, which handles trade relations between the two regions. This structure reflects the continued economic and diplomatic engagement between Hong Kong and Malaysia, even as formal sovereignty shifted in 1997.<cite>[S5]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Hong Kong–Malaysia relations


# Hong Kong–Malaysia relations



**Hong Kong–Malaysia relations** (Chinese: 香港與馬來西亞的關係 *Xiānggǎng yǔ mǎláixīyà de guānxì*; Malay: *Hubungan Hong Kong–Malaysia*; Jawi: هوبوڠن هونج كونج–مليسيا) refers to bilateral diplomatic relations between Hong Kong and Malaysia. [S2] Hong Kong enjoys significant autonomy in economic, trade, financial and monetary matters, Both regions were colonized by the British Empire and are Cantonese-Speaking. [S3] Malaysia maintains a consulate general office in Hong Kong. [S4] ## Diplomatic representation

As a Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong is formally represented in Malaysia by the Chinese Embassy in Kuala Lumpur. [S5] Hong Kong's trade relations with Malaysia are handled by the Hong Kong Trade and Development Council in Kuala Lumpur. [S6] Malaysia did not establish diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China until 31 May 1974. [S7] Malaysia has a Consulate General in Wan Chai. [S8] This was established on 2 July 1971. [S9] As Hong Kong was then under British rule, this was then known as a **Commission**, as were the missions of some other Commonwealth countries. [S10] Following the transfer of sovereignty in 1997, the commission was renamed the Consulate General, and the last Commissioner became Consul-General. [S11] The current Consul-General of Malaysia in Hong Kong is Yap Wei Sin who took up the post in March 2019. [S12] ## Economic relations

In 2010, Malaysia became the 10th largest trading partner for Hong Kong with the total trade increased from HK$87.2 billion in 2009 to HK$110.5 billion. [S13] These total trade was later increase to $14.65 billion in 2013. [S14] Malaysia also became one of the 18th largest investors into Hong Kong in 2009, with an Inward Direct Investment (IDI) stock of HK$16.5 billion, while Hong Kong investment to Malaysia worth to HK$43.9 billion. [S15] In 2010, Hong Kong became the third largest foreign direct investment (FDI) in Malaysia with a total investments of
RM2.77 billion in 11 projects comprising nine new projects and other two expansion/diversification projects. [S16] There are 7 regional headquarters, 19 regional offices and 33 local offices which been set up by the Malaysian companies in Hong Kong. [S17] An agreement on double tax avoidance and prevention of fiscal evasion was signed in 2012. [S18] ## Medical tourism

As of 2012, the number of visitors from China (including Hong Kong) to Malaysia for medical treatment has doubled, from 7,500 in 2010 to 15,000.

**Hong Kong–Malaysia relations** (Chinese: 香港與馬來西亞的關係 *Xiānggǎng yǔ mǎláixīyà de guānxì*; Malay: *Hubungan Hong Kong–Malaysia*; Jawi: هوبوڠن هونج كونج–مليسيا) refers to bilateral diplomatic relations between Hong Kong and Malaysia. Putting it all together: During the British era, Malaysia's mission was a Commission, later renamed Consulate General after 1997. Current structure includes the Consulate General in Wan Chai and the Chinese Embassy's role. Also, the Trade Council handles trade relations.

qa_pairs.question: What were the key economic indicators of trade and investment between Hong Kong and Malaysia from 2009 to 2013, and how did these figures reflect their bilateral economic ties?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>In 2010, Malaysia became the 10th largest trading partner for Hong Kong, with total trade increasing from HK$87.2 billion in 2009 to HK$110.5 billion. By 2013, total trade further increased to $14.65 billion. These figures highlight growing trade volumes between the two regions during 2009–2013.<cite>[S13][S14]</cite></statement><statement>Malaysia was one of the 18th largest investors into Hong Kong in 2009, with an Inward Direct Investment (IDI) stock of HK$16.5 billion, while Hong Kong’s investment in Malaysia reached HK$43.9 billion. This reflects mutual investment interests and economic interdependence.<cite>[S15]</cite></statement><statement>In 2010, Hong Kong became the third largest foreign direct investment (FDI) in Malaysia, with RM2.77 billion in investments across 11 projects. This underscores Hong Kong’s significant role as an investment hub for Malaysian businesses.<cite>[S16]</cite></statement><statement>Malaysian companies established 7 regional headquarters, 19 regional offices, and 33 local offices in Hong Kong, indicating a strong economic presence and operational integration between the two regions.<cite>[S17]</cite></statement><statement>An agreement on double tax avoidance and fiscal evasion was signed in 2012, aiming to enhance trade and investment cooperation by reducing tax barriers.<cite>[S18]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What was the impact of the 2012 double tax avoidance agreement on Hong Kong-Malaysia economic relations, and how did medical tourism trends reflect their bilateral engagement?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The 2012 double tax avoidance agreement between Hong Kong and Malaysia likely enhanced economic cooperation by addressing tax barriers, though the passage explicitly notes the agreement's signing in [S18].<cite>[S18]</cite></statement> <statement>Medical tourism trends reflected bilateral engagement, as the number of visitors from China (including Hong Kong) to Malaysia for medical treatment doubled from 7,500 in 2010 to 15,000 by 2012, indicating growing cross-border health-related interactions.<cite>[S19]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: How does the Hong Kong Trade and Development Council facilitate economic relations between Hong Kong and Malaysia, and what role do Malaysian companies play in Hong Kong's business landscape?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Hong Kong Trade and Development Council facilitates economic relations between Hong Kong and Malaysia by handling Hong Kong's trade relations with Malaysia from its office in Kuala Lumpur.<cite>[S5]</cite></statement> <statement>Malaysian companies play a significant role in Hong Kong's business landscape through the establishment of 7 regional headquarters, 19 regional offices, and 33 local offices in Hong Kong.<cite>[S17]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Hong Kong–Malaysia relations


# Hong Kong–Malaysia relations



**Hong Kong–Malaysia relations** (Chinese: 香港與馬來西亞的關係 *Xiānggǎng yǔ mǎláixīyà de guānxì*; Malay: *Hubungan Hong Kong–Malaysia*; Jawi: هوبوڠن هونج كونج–مليسيا) refers to bilateral diplomatic relations between Hong Kong and Malaysia. [S2] Hong Kong enjoys significant autonomy in economic, trade, financial and monetary matters, Both regions were colonized by the British Empire and are Cantonese-Speaking. [S3] Malaysia maintains a consulate general office in Hong Kong. [S4] ## Diplomatic representation

As a Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong is formally represented in Malaysia by the Chinese Embassy in Kuala Lumpur. [S5] Hong Kong's trade relations with Malaysia are handled by the Hong Kong Trade and Development Council in Kuala Lumpur. [S6] Malaysia did not establish diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China until 31 May 1974. [S7] Malaysia has a Consulate General in Wan Chai. [S8] This was established on 2 July 1971. [S9] As Hong Kong was then under British rule, this was then known as a **Commission**, as were the missions of some other Commonwealth countries. [S10] Following the transfer of sovereignty in 1997, the commission was renamed the Consulate General, and the last Commissioner became Consul-General. [S11] The current Consul-General of Malaysia in Hong Kong is Yap Wei Sin who took up the post in March 2019. [S12] ## Economic relations

In 2010, Malaysia became the 10th largest trading partner for Hong Kong with the total trade increased from HK$87.2 billion in 2009 to HK$110.5 billion. [S13] These total trade was later increase to $14.65 billion in 2013. [S14] Malaysia also became one of the 18th largest investors into Hong Kong in 2009, with an Inward Direct Investment (IDI) stock of HK$16.5 billion, while Hong Kong investment to Malaysia worth to HK$43.9 billion. [S15] In 2010, Hong Kong became the third largest foreign direct investment (FDI) in Malaysia with a total investments of
RM2.77 billion in 11 projects comprising nine new projects and other two expansion/diversification projects. [S16] There are 7 regional headquarters, 19 regional offices and 33 local offices which been set up by the Malaysian companies in Hong Kong. [S17] An agreement on double tax avoidance and prevention of fiscal evasion was signed in 2012. [S18] ## Medical tourism

As of 2012, the number of visitors from China (including Hong Kong) to Malaysia for medical treatment has doubled, from 7,500 in 2010 to 15,000.

So the answer should have two statements: one citing S5 for the HKTDC's role and another citing S17 for Malaysian companies' presence. I need to structure each statement properly with the citations.
